label: Self Efficacy Multiplier
description: This refers to an individual's belief in their ability to successfully adopt and maintain a sustainable diet. If people feel confident that they can make dietary changes without significant hardship, they are more likely to shift toward sustainable eating habits.

label: Response Efficacy Multiplier
description: This reflects the belief that adopting a sustainable diet will effectively contribute to positive environmental or health outcomes. If individuals perceive that their actions will have a meaningful impact, they are more likely to change their behavior.

label: Perceived Risks Multiplier
description: These are the potential negative consequences that individuals associate with shifting to a sustainable diet, such as concerns about nutritional deficiencies, higher costs, or difficulty in accessing sustainable food options. Higher perceived risks may discourage people from making dietary changes.

label: Perceived Risks (No Education)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate NoEd Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Primary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Primary Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Secondary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Secondary Variation

label: Perceived Risks (Tertiary)
varname: Climate Risk Perception Rate Tertiary Variation

label: Social Norms Multiplier
description: These refer to the influence of societal and peer expectations on an individual’s diet choices. If sustainable eating is widely accepted and promoted within social circles or society at large, individuals are more likely to adopt such diets to align with prevailing norms.
